message.content: This question requires some basic knowledge of cooling mechanisms. Water (H2O) is commonly used as a coolant for engines because of its high heat capacity and ability to conduct heat away from the engine. Option (B) is incorrect because fire would actually generate heat, not cool the engine. Option (C) is incorrect because salt does not have cooling properties. Option (D) is incorrect because corn cannot act as a coolant.

This question requires knowledge about the properties of different materials and their ability to cool an engine. Water (H2O) is commonly used as a coolant in engines because of its high specific heat capacity, which allows it to absorb and carry away heat effectively. Option (B) is incorrect because fire would actually generate more heat and increase the temperature of the engine. Option (C) is unrelated to cooling and is commonly used as a seasoning. Option (D) is also unrelated to cooling and is commonly used as a food source.

Water has high specific heat capacity, meaning it can absorb a lot of heat without significantly increasing in temperature. This makes it an effective coolant for engines. Option (B) is incorrect because fire in a house would not be used to cool an engine. Option (C) is unrelated to cooling. Option (D) is not used as a coolant in engines.
